items.title: 90% of Startups Fail. DeSilo Changes That.
items.description:
Most startups don't fail from bad ideas‚Äîthey fail from bad access. The data is clear: where you are and who you know determines whether you succeed more than talent or hustle.
42% build something nobody wants. 29% never apply for funding they'd qualify for. 73% of fintech startups die from regulatory blindspots they didn't see coming.
We're building DeSilo to fix this‚Äîa tool that puts accelerator-level intelligence in every founder's hands.

items.title: India's Emergency Response is Broken. Here's How AI Fixes It.
items.description:
Every year, India loses 2.4 million people to treatable conditions ‚Äî heart attacks, road accidents, snakebites, maternal emergencies.

The treatments exist. The hospitals exist. The ambulances exist.

What's missing is coordination.

Only 7% of trauma patients in India reach a hospital within the "Golden Hour" ‚Äî that critical 60-minute window when intervention saves lives. In the US, it's over 50%.

This video proposes Golden Hour ‚Äî a voice-first, AI-powered emergency response system t...

items.title: Why Artists Hate Their Own Work (And Why That‚Äôs Okay)
items.description:
If you make anything - paintings, photos, podcasts - you probably hate your own work the moment it‚Äôs finished, then cringe at it years later. In this Idea Sandbox clip, artist Preeti Varma explains why that‚Äôs a normal part of the creative process, describing how she constantly walks toward and away from her canvas, looking at it from different angles until she reaches a personal ‚Äúpoint of resolution‚Äù.‚Äã‚Äã

items.title: Can Civil Society Save India‚Äôs Democracy?
items.description:
What will really save Indian democracy - elections every five years, or ordinary people saying ‚Äúenough is enough‚Äù. 
In this Idea Sandbox clip, veteran journalist Kalpana argues that only civil society, youth movements and independent digital media can stop India sliding into division and violence between citizens. items.title: India‚Äôs Architecture of Chaos: Rahul Mehrotra Explains Our 4 Ways of Building
items.description: Since India‚Äôs economic liberalisation in 1990, our cities have become a cacophony of architectures - glass towers, regional buildings, alternative craft projects and brand new ‚Äúancient‚Äù temples all jostling on the same streets. items.title: India‚Äôs Street Dog Crisis: Too Poor To Care?
items.description:
Why do India and Nepal treat street dogs so differently from pampered pet dogs - is it cruelty, culture, caste or just poverty. In this Idea Sandbox clip, glaciologist and animal-welfare researcher Dr. Julie Palais explains that many families in India and Nepal are living on the edge, spending hours commuting and just trying to survive each day, so they simply don‚Äôt have the money, time or bandwidth to adopt and care for stray dogs.‚Äã‚Äã

items.title: Bombay vs Mumbai: The Hidden Cost of Renaming Our Cities
items.description:
India is in a frenzy of renaming cities from Bombay to Mumbai and Bangalore to Bengaluru but almost nobody talks about the hidden cost of changing a city‚Äôs name. In this Idea Sandbox clip, Harvard GSD professor and architect Rahul Mehrotra explains why cities are actually brands with decades of global recognition, cultural memory and economic value attached to their names.‚Äã

items.title: 1 Death Every 3 Minutes: India's Road Crisis Exposed
items.description: India tops global road fatalities with 168,000 deaths in 2022 alone - that's 465 Indians dying daily in road accidents, boiling down to ONE DEATH EVERY 3 MINUTES on our highways and streets. In this explosive Idea Sandbox clip, co-host Kishore unleashes a raw rant on why India leads the world in road deaths, slamming the transport minister and MPs for zero accountability as 10 people perish while they joke around. items.title: Why Indians Don‚Äôt Want Salon Jobs (And Who‚Äôs Doing Them Instead)
items.description:

items.title: Cities Are Made, Not Found: Mumbai, Bangalore and Our Passive Citizens
items.description:

items.title: Why No One Wants Kids Anymore: Stanford Sociologist Explains Japan & South Korea‚Äôs Baby Crisis
items.description:
Across Japan, South Korea and other rich countries, birth rates are falling so fast that governments are begging people to go home, have sex and make more babies. Yet nothing changes.
